required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Relationship Between Exercise Frequency, Intensity, and Restoration of Cardiometabolic Health
clinical_study.official_title: The Relationship Between Exercise Frequency, Intensity, and Restoration of Cardiometabolic Health

brief_summary.textblock:
Regular physical activity is well established to decrease the risk of cardiometabolic diseases, however these beneficial effects are largely dependent on the type of exercise protocol conducted. The purpose of this study is to directly compare the efficacy of endurance (END), sprint (SIT), or combined endurance-sprint (COMB) training in respect to reducing clinically relevant cardiometabolic risk factors in pre-diabetic individuals. It is hypothesized that:
1. END and COMB will elicit favourable cardiovascular adaptations, which will be absent in response to SIT.
2. END and COMB protocols of greater frequency will markedly improve metabolic health in comparison to a lower frequency SIT protocol.

detailed_description.textblock:
Involvement in regular physical activity is known to elicit systemic adaptations and reduce the risk of cardiometabolic diseases, including hypertension, obesity, dyslipidemia, and hyperglycemia. Traditional physical activity recommendations suggested 150 minutes of moderate-intensity continuous endurance (END) exercise dispersed over 5 days per week was sufficient to improve physical fitness in adults. However, given the commonly cited barrier of "lack of time," literature has recently focused on time effective sprint interval training (SIT), obtaining equivalent increases in aerobic capacity and acute glycemic regulation compared to classical END exercise. Despite these similarities, END is conducive to daily sessions not feasible of SIT training. As many clinically relevant risk factors are transient in nature, it remains imperative to assess the implications of variable frequency exercise regimes. An additional notable and novel discrepancy between protocols includes the improved arterial compliance in response to END while these adaptations have largely been absent following interval training. This parameter, representing relevant cardiovascular risk reduction, warrants further attention especially when assessing clinical populations.
While current research has largely centred on distinct END or SIT protocols, an application includes integrating both types of exercise into a combined endurance-sprint (COMB) protocol to achieve a greater frequency while maintaining some sessions at a higher intensity. As END and SIT may induce opposing cardiovascular outcomes, a combination may mitigate these SIT-induced effects and prove to be an ideal exercise prescription. Investigating the cardiovascular and metabolic adaptations in response to END, SIT, and COMB protocols will provide an integrated analysis of relevant health parameters in clinical populations. This research will assist in establishing an optimal exercise protocol for preventative and treatment approaches in individuals who are at risk for developing chronic health conditions.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: This study is a 6-week exercise training study, with three possible parallel training groups: endurance (END), sprint (SIT) or combined endurance-sprint (COMB) training.

primary_outcome.measure: Change from Baseline Cardiorespiratory Fitness Chronically at 6 Weeks
Change in Baseline Blood Glucose Levels Chronically at 6 Weeks
Change in Baseline Blood Glucose Levels Acutely Post-Exercise

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Baseline Fasting Blood High-density lipoprotein (HDL) Chronically at 6 Weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Blood lipid profile from fasted venous blood sampling

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Baseline Fasting Blood Low-density Lipoprotein (LDL) Chronically at 6 Weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Blood lipid profile from fasted venous blood sampling

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Baseline Fasting Blood High-sensitivity C-reactive Protein (CRP) Chronically at 6 Weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Blood lipid profile from fasted venous blood sampling

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Baseline Fasting Total Cholesterol Chronically at 6 Weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Blood lipid profile from fasted venous blood sampling

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Baseline Fasting Triglycerides (TAG) Chronically at 6 Weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Blood lipid profile from fasted venous blood sampling

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Baseline Post-prandial Blood Lipids Chronically at 6 Weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Assessed following the consumption of an oral fat tolerance test (OFTT): triglycerides (TAG) and free fatty acids (FFA)

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Resting Daily Blood Pressure
secondary_outcome.description: Assessed via brachial blood pressure cuff reading

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Baseline Body Composition Chronically at 6 Weeks
Change in Baseline Central Arterial Stiffness Chronically at 6 Weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Assessed via carotid-femoral pulse wave velocity (PWV)

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Baseline Central Arterial Stiffness Acutely Post-Exercise
secondary_outcome.description: Assessed via carotid-femoral pulse wave velocity (PWV)

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Baseline Brachial Artery Vascular Function (Flow Mediated Dilation, FMD) Chronically at 6 Weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Assessed via brachial artery flow mediated dilation (FMD)

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Baseline Brachial Artery Vascular Function (Flow Mediated Dilation, FMD) Acutely Post-Exercise
secondary_outcome.description: Assessed via brachial artery flow mediated dilation (FMD)

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Baseline Daily Sedentary Time Chronically at 6 Weeks
Change in Baseline Daily Sedentary Time Acutely Post-Exercise

arm_group.description: This group is performing END training for 6 weeks in duration. Intervention: Behavioral: Endurance Exercise Training (END)
This group is performing SIT training for 6 weeks in duration. Intervention: Behavioral: Sprint Exercise Training (SIT)
This group is performing COMB training for 6 weeks in duration. Intervention: Behavioral: Combined Endurance-Sprint Exercise Training (COMB)

intervention.description: Physical activity will be conducted on cycle ergometers under supervision. Participants will exercise 5 days a week for 20-25 minutes (Week 1); 30 minutes (Weeks 2-4); or 35 minutes (Weeks 5-6) at 60% VO2 peak.

Physical activity will be conducted on cycle ergometers under supervision. Participants will exercise 3 days a week involving a 3-minute warm-up, followed up 4 repetitions (Week 1); 5 repetitions (Weeks 2-4); or 6 (Weeks 5-6) repetitions of 30 seconds at a maximal intensity with 2.5 minutes' rest in between. Exercise will conclude with a 2 minute cool-down.

Physical activity will be conducted on cycle ergometers under supervision. Participants will exercise 5 days a week alternating between the endurance session (Mon/Wed/Fri) and the sprint session (Tues/Thurs).

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Male, aged 45-70 years
- Fasting blood glucose between 6-13.9mM
- Body mass index (BMI) > 25 kg/m^2
- Sedentary (<60 minutes moderate physical activity per week)
- Physician approval for vigorous exercise
Exclusion Criteria:
- Prescribed with glucose lowering medications
- Smoker
- Not cleared for physical activity by a physician

responsible_party.investigator_title: Dr. Jamie Burr, Director, Human Performance and Health Laboratory, Principal Investigator, Assistant Professor, PhD
